titleStmt.title: Inscription in honour of Honorius Caesar from Aphrodisias by Tatianus praet. prefect

availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

msIdentifier.repository: Aphrodisias, Hadrianic baths, North-Eastern corner of the East forecourt colonnade

summary.term: Honorary inscription to the emperor Honorius

layout.p: The text is inscribed on the face. Letters are clear and irregular.
layout.rs: The inscription is complete, but most of lines 5 and 6 of the inscription have been deliberately erased. The upper edge of the column is broken.

history.provenance: Aphrodisias, Hadrianic baths (“Les Thermes”), North side of the East forecourt

div.ab:
τὸν ἐκ τῆς θείας γονῆς
θεοφιλέστατον
Φλ(άουιον) Ὁνώριον
τὸν ἐπιφανέστατον
Φλάουιος Εὐτόλμιος Τατιανὸς ὁ λαμπρότατος
ἔπαρχος τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραιτωρίου
τῇ συνήθει καθοσιώσει
ἀφιέρωσεν
ἐπὶ Ἀντωνίου Πρίσκου τοῦ λαμπροτάτου ἡγεμόνος.

div.p: This edition follows the text edited by Roueché 1989, nr. 25.

app.note: Reinach read nothing; Robert 1948 read Φλ Εὐτόλμιος Τατια

div.p: “A Flavius Honorius, progenie imperiale (= porfirogenito), carissimo a Dio, nobilissimo (fanciullo), Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, chiarissimo prefetto del sacro pretorio consacrò (la statua) con la consueta devozione, mentre era chiarissimo governatore Antonius Priscus.”

“To Flavius Honorius, of divine descent, most dear to God, the most noble, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, prefect of the sacred praetorium man of clarissimus rank, dedicated (this statue) with the customary devotion, in the time of Antonius Priscus, the governor, man of clarissimus rank.”

“À Flavius Honorius, progéniture impériale (= porphyrogenitus), très cher à Dieu, très noble (enfant), Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, le clarissime préfet du sacré prétoire, a consacré (la statue) avec la dévotion habituelle, alors qu’il était gouverneur clarissime Antonius Priscus.”

The column base was found at Aphrodisias in 1904 by Paul Gaudin in the northern side of the east forecourt of the Hadrianic Bath. It is currently located on the south side of the northern pedestals in the north-eastern corner of the forecourt. The upper edge of the inscribed monument has been cut off and, on the left upper edge, there are traces left by a clamp probably when the inscribed monument was reused.

The honorary inscription for the emperor Honorius was one of a group of statues honouring the members of Theodosian imperial family at Aphrodisias (see also PPRET 83, Arcadius, 84, Valentinianus II; other statues were erected by Tatianus honouring the whole imperial college at Side, 85, and at Antinoupolis, 86).

Most of lines 5 and 6 of the inscription have been erased but can be restored. The legibility of some of the erased letters, together with comparison between this inscription and similar honours awarded to Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, allow us to restore the text.

Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus (see PLRE I Tatianus 5) was a notable pagan. He was made praetorian prefect in the East in 388 AD and fell from power in 392 AD. After suffering damnatio memoriae he was banished to Lycia. He was rehabilitated posthumously by a descendant in Aphrodisias (PPRET 91). His whole career is recorded in ascending order of importance from praeses (ἡγεμών) to praefectus (ἔπαρχος) in the inscription from Sidyma (see PPRET 87).

Antonius Priscus, governor of the Caria (PLRE I, p. 730), is known only by the series of the three inscriptions dedicated by Tatianus at Aphrodisias (PPRET 82-84). In the inscription in honour of Honorius Caesar his name is preserved, but in the two inscriptions in honour of Arcadius and Valentiniaus II his name has been erased. Priscus was probably a client of the powerful praetorian prefect. Tatianus ordered the governor of the province to follow the realization of the monuments.

div.p: ὁ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραιτωρίου
